Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Intra-operative Ventilation Strategies in Obese Patients

Trial_Design.evidence: The sample size was calculated to detect a 10% relative increase in dependent lung ventilation with 80% power and α = 0.05.

Participants.evidence: Participants included 162 patients with a BMI of at least 35 kg/m² undergoing elective open or laparoscopic surgery lasting at least 120 minutes.

Intervention.evidence: Patients were randomised to receive either PEEP of 4 cmH₂O (n = 79) or PEEP of 12 cmH₂O with hourly ARMs (n = 83).

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the effects of different PEEP levels and ARMs on ventilation distribution, oxygenation, haemodynamic parameters, and cerebral oximetry.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the fraction of ventilation in the dependent lung, measured by electrical impedance tomography over the intra-operative period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Participants included 162 patients... Patients were randomised to receive either PEEP of 4 cmH₂O (n = 79) or PEEP of 12 cmH₂O with hourly ARMs (n = 83).

Result_Outcome.evidence: High PEEP was associated with smaller decreases in dependent lung ventilation (-11.2%; 95% CI -8.7 to -13.7 vs. -13.9%; 95% CI -11.7 to -16.5; P = 0.029) and a lower driving pressure (-6.3 cmH₂O; 95% CI -5.7 to -7.0).
